thread.title: Calvary sweeps Strong Rock Christian to advance to Columbus
thread.title_full: Calvary sweeps Strong Rock Christian to advance to Columbus | savannahnow.com

author: Dennis Knight
title: Calvary sweeps Strong Rock Christian to advance to Columbus
text:
Photos Dennis Knight/Savannah Morning News
Calvary Day senior Jessica Ginn delivers a pitch to Strong Rock Christian’s Abby Young on Wednesday in the first game of series sweep by the host Cavaliers.
By Dennis Knight When the tension rose in Calvary Day’s softball playoff series with visiting Strong Rock Christian on Wednesday, Cavalier pitcher Jessica Ginn never let the pressure get to her — facing each situation with a positive attitude and often with a smile on her face.
Ginn’s cool temperament helped win the day for Calvary as she stayed relaxed and delivered in clutch moments in the pitching circle and at the plate — helping lead the Cavaliers to a 3-2, 5-3 sweep of Strong Rock Christian.
Calvary Day (19-12) advanced to the Class A Private School Elite Eight for the second straight year. The Cavaliers will play their next game in Columbus on Oct. 29.
“It’s natural for me. Growing up, I was told to never show emotion when I got mad at myself,” said Ginn, who is 19-12 this season. “When you have a good attitude, you will play your best, and that’s what I try to do when I’m pitching.”
The second game went to extra innings tied at 3-3, with the international tie-breaker in effect. Gracie Hartzog started the top of the eighth at second for the Cavaliers and came into score on a bunt single by Ny’Taisha Willis. Katie Miller and Abbey Slingluff also had bunt singles in the frame, setting up Ginn with the bases loaded. She responded with a sacrifice fly to center that gave Calvary a 5-3 lead.
“I was impressed with our perseverance,” Calvary coach Sherry Griffin said. “We made some errors that cost us, but we fought through to get those 21 outs and advance to the next level. Jessica (Ginn) plays her position well, she won’t let a call affect her next pitch.”
In the second game, the Cavaliers took the lead in the second inning. Hartzog drove in a run with a sacrifice bunt, and Slingluff, who was 3 for 4 in the second game, brought home another with a single to left. Ginn’s RBI infield single put the Cavs up 3-0.
But the Patriots rallied in the bottom of the third when Annie Corbin led off the inning with a homer to left. A pair of Calvary errors led to another run, but Ginn kept her head up and got out of the inning. The Patriots tied it up at 3-3 in the fifth when Kyndal Brown drove a shot just out of the reach of Calvary second baseman Miller, who laid out with a backhand dive at the ball.
The Patriots had the tying run at second in the bottom of the eighth, with the dangerous Corbin at the plate. She hit a sizzling liner to third, where Sydney Wilson made the grab to clinch the series.
“I try not to panic in those kind of situations,” Wilson said. “It was just a reaction on that last out.”
In the first game, Ginn went 2 for 3 with a pair of runs, and went the distance in the pitching circle. When Strong Rock scored a pair of runs to cut the Calvary lead to 3-2 with the tying run at first — Ginn induced Madisyn Brown to ground out to Wilson to end the game. Ginn scored a run on a second-inning error, and Wilson delivered a clutch two-run single up the middle as the Cavs went up 3-0, after a leadoff triple by Morgan Sterrett in the fifth.
“Jessica (Ginn), Sydney (Wilson), Morgan (Sterrett) and Catie Thomas have been hitting in the clutch for us all season, and they continued to do that when it counted today,” Griffin said.
The Cavaliers will make the trip to Columbus next week to meet an opponent to be determined.
“We want to go out there and play as well as we can,” Wilson said. “We want to finish strong.”
CALVARY 3,
STRONG ROCK 2

CDS 001 020 x - 3 5 0
W-Jessica Ginn. L-Abby Young. Leading hitters—CDS, Morgan Sterrett 1-3, 3B, run; Ginn 2-3, 2 runs; Sydney Wilson 1-2, 2 RBI; Catie Thomas 1-3. SR, Olivia Biles 2-4, Paula Drake 1-4, 2 RBI; Young 3-3.
